title: 103_hr3885
content:
SHORT TITLE, FINDINGS. The Act may be cited as "Fire Safe Cigarette Act of 1994". Congress finds that cigarette ignited fires are the leading cause of fire deaths in the United States, resulting in numerous deaths, injuries, and property damage. Over 100 children are killed each year from cigarette related fires. Congress deems it necessary to establish a cigarette fire safety standard for manufacture and importation. The Consumer Product Safety Commission found that the cost of not having a cigarette fire safety standard is $4 billion annually, supporting the implementation of such a standard using their regulatory expertise. SEC. 2. CIGARETTE FIRE SAFETY STANDARD. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must issue a cigarette fire safety standard within one year of this Act's enactment to reduce the risk of cigarette ignition. The Commission must consult with relevant agencies and consider existing low ignition propensity cigarettes on the market. The Consumer Product Safety Commission must issue a cigarette fire safety standard within one year of this Act's enactment to reduce the risk of cigarette ignition. The rule will prohibit stockpiling of cigarettes not meeting the standard and will be issued in accordance with section 553 of title 5, United States Code, with an effective date no later than 2 years after the Act's enactment. Judicial review can be sought by any person affected by the rule within 60 days of its issuance. The petition can be filed with the United States Court of Appeals for review. The Commission must provide the court with the record of the proceedings on which the rule is based. The petitioner can request to add additional evidence before the court, which may be taken before the Commission for consideration. The Commission can adjust its findings based on the new evidence. The court has jurisdiction over the petition for judicial review within 60 days of the rule's issuance. Upon filing a petition, the court has jurisdiction to review the Commission's rule in accordance with title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. ENFORCEMENT. Prohibits the manufacture or import of cigarettes that do not comply with a fire safety standard. Violations are considered a violation of the Consumer Product Safety Act. 

SEC. 4. PREEMPTION. This Act and the fire safety standard do not affect state laws with stricter standards. Compliance with the standard cannot be used as a defense in civil actions.

SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS.

The term "Commission" refers to the Consumer Product Safety Commission, and "cigarette" is defined as per the Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act.
